APPROPRIATION BILL


    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee

    of Supply [3rd Allotted Day]:

    Resumption of debate on Question (17th December,

    1957) proposed to Head 25 in the First Schedule of

    the Bill,

    "That the sum to be allotted for Head 25 be reduced

    by $120,000 in respect of subhead 33 therein."-(Mr

    R. Jumabhoy).

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

FIRST SCHEDULE


    Head 25 -

    Question again proposed.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang (Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the limited time allotted, I propose to go direct to the point to give the others a chance to speak.

    Sir, this is the third time I have to announce to the people of Singapore the Government's wasteful policy in coming here and asking for a grant of a large sum of the ratepayers' money for a useless purpose like family planning. I say "useless" because to a Question I put to this House last month asking for birth statistics for two periods, I got a reply which showed that births had increased instead of decreased. In other words, family planning is a failure. Indeed, Sir, the Family Planning Association admits it in page 5 of their Seventh Annual Report which reads as follows:

    "No one is more conscious than we of the fact that family planning cannot hope to provide a solution to the problems which face Singapore with a population which is likely to treble itself in less than 30 years."

    Sir, knowing this, I think the Association should have the conscience to give up and make a retreat. Instead of that, they come to ask for money to be wasted. I now await to see what the attitude of the Government is. As for myself, I strongly object to the grant.

    The Chairman: I think the Chief Minister did announce that there is going to be a free vote.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Yes, that is right.

Column: 3154



    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): They still rule.

    Mr R. C. H. Lim (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think it will be extremely unfair not to make this grant to the Family Planning Association. It will not only disorganise that Association and may render the members thereof liable for damages for one month's pay in lieu of notice, etc., but it will cause great hardship to those women who have been accustomed in the last few years to come to "the Association" for advice and for other forms of assistance. We must at least make this grant this year.

    During this present Session of the Assembly, we have had the Estimates Committee sitting and, if some Members are not satisfied with the way in which the Association has spent the money, the matter could be referred to the Estimates Committee for the next Session to investigate into how the money was spent and a report will be made. If, as a result of the investigation by the Estimates Committee, we find that the money had been wasted, then we can reconsider the matter next year but it would be very unfair indeed to refuse this grant without notice this year.

    Sir, I therefore appeal to Members to take these two points into consideration when deciding whether this grant should or should not be made.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, it was rather a funny argument by the hon, nominated Member Mr R. C. H. Lim. He said that it would cause hardship to families. Have we not got our hospitals? Have we not got our clinics? Can these people not be attended to there? How much is one month's pay in lieu of notice? Is that not better rather than to keep on paying $120,000 a year?

    But, Sir, yesterday, I said that I moved this amendment with an open mind and pointed out that I did so on certain principles. I mean no disrespect to the honorary workers of the Family Planning Association who are giving of their time and not money because they only contributed $1,000, as laid down in their own pamphlet.

Column: 3155



    Now, Sir, the question was raised yesterday about the Jams. It is a very important religion which is one of the recognised religions of India in the world. Why should we not show respect to its followers if they raise certain objections? One of their beliefs is that you should not kill even an ant if you can help it. Now, Sir, there is also a religious body here which is an inter-religious body consisting of various religious heads. Have they been consulted as to whether they approve of it on religious grounds? Has the Muslim Chief Kathi of Singapore been consulted?

    The Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing (Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat): I have.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Now, Islam is definitely against unnatural practices but it also stresses that if a woman does not want to have children for reasons of health, she can take all the precautionary measures possible. There is no question about that. The main reason of the objectors is that their money should not be spent or given away. Let me also say, Mr Speaker, that possibly due to the prayers of these religious objectors, the Labour Front has lost four of its Members including the ex-Chief Minister (Mr D. S. Marshall). Possibly they may lose all; the time is not far off.

    Now, Sir, I said that there is strong objection to family planning on religious grounds but my objection is this, that you are giving away $120,000 to a body for a purpose which may be good but how much are they raising themselves? It is only $1,100. Now, has the Government any control whatsoever over the administration? We have received another pamphlet from the objectors giving us the number of hours they work in the Association and so on, and informing us that $83,000 was spent on salaries and provident fund. Now. Sir, if the Government is giving so much money, why not run this department on their own in the interests of the public? We are not against that because with the increase in population, Singapore may not be large enough to accommodate everybody.

Column: 3156

No taxpayer then can object to that but what they are objecting to is giving away $120,000 to this particular body which can only raise $1,000 itself. But it seems that there is to be a free vote. I would still like to hear arguments in favour of why Government should give $120,000 to a body which raises only $1,000 through subscriptions and maybe through other sources. That is a different thing altogether.

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Mr Speaker, Sir, this is the third year in which this subject has been raised in the Assembly. Everything that could be said one way or another has been previously expressed most forcefully and must be clear in the minds of those present, because the set-up of this House is the same as has been during the last two years with the exception of the new Member for Cairnhill (Mr Soh Ghee Soon) - I am sure that he has taken an interest in this matter and read up our local Hansards on what has been said on this subject in the past. I agree with Mr R. C. H. Lim that no further time should be wasted on detailed arguments. My stand however in this is quite clear. I can only repeat what I have said in the past and that my stand on this subject in supporting the mover of the amendment is the same as it was and ever will be.

    While I agree with the Member for Telok Ayer (Mr R. Jumabhoy) that there should not be discrimination on the question of religions, when he was discussing the ecclesiastical votes, I would like to point out that this is not a question of religion and religion should not be an issue. The two issues as I see it before the House are (1) the complete deletion of a vote for $120,000 to the Family Planning Association and (2) whether the increase of $20,000 is justified. I am in full accord with all those who say that the taxpayers' money should not be used in something that is against the very tenets of their religion or against their conscience and Government should not bulldoze through its policy by compelling the taxpayers to contribute to something

Column: 3157

which they think is really wrong. On that point, everything that could be said has been said.

10.15 a.m.

    I can furthermore see no justification whatsoever for this increase of $20,000. The increase of grants to this Association has gone up from the paltry sum of $5,000 to $10,000, $30,000, $45,000, $60.000, $80,000, $85,000, $100,000 and now it is going up to $120,000. I would like to know where this will all end when there are other most deserving charitable causes like the Home for the Blind, the Little Sisters of the Poor, the Ramakrishna Mission and several other missions whose needs are far greater than those of the Family Planning Association which could, with voluntary effort, raise their own funds, as pointed out by the Member for Telok Ayer. I think that it is a wasteful act to allot such a vast sum to an Association the majority of whose sister bodies in other parts of the world are self-supporting.

    I support the motion which was moved by the Member for Telok Ayer.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, I think I have to continue with my reply to the speech of the Minister for Communications and Works yesterday.

    I agree that we should not repeat and repeat the same old story again on this controversial subject but I would like to raise three points for the House to consider. Firstly, on this issue are we not defeatists? We have no hope to provide for what we have to provide. The Minister for Communications and Works has warned us that there is a rapid growth of population in the whole world and that therefore Singapore should be on the safe side to be able to provide the means of livelihood for the people. Sir, I stated yesterday that we are in the age of the hydrogen bomb and that we are about to conquer space. I mentioned also that the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom has hopes of drawing power from the sea instead of from coal

Column: 3158

dug by miners. In the old days travel from the United Kingdom to Singapore took months but now it takes just over two days by Comet. Therefore, in the same way, we should strive through hard work to produce an ideal system of society. Sir, I strongly object to the unnatural practice of birth control and one must have strong faith in an ideal social system with a fair distribution of wealth. I am sure that many office-bearers of the Family Planning Association have a so-called small family. To them, two or three children are really sufficient and more would be troublesome but I am sure that their houses must have many rooms. Sir, I think the Minister for Communications and Works knows where I stay. I have a room which I occupy and based on the standard of the houses of those office-bearers it would qualify as a servant's room. But I have five children and I am very proud of them. Sir, if one has hopes of conquering space in the future and of many scientific improvements, we should not therefore worry about the rapid increase in population. We must not think that if we limit the growth of population, there will be less delinquents and illiteracy in society. We should build more schools and more hospitals rather than say, "We should limit the number of patients to the hospitals or limit the number of new pupils to the schools."

    Secondly, Sir, the argument is that Singapore is a small island of 224 square miles and that the population in 1965 will be about 2 million. Sir, why can we not look forward to a merger with the Federation of Malaya? The all-Party agreement in this House is that we must merge with the Federation of Malaya. We may be citizens of the Federation of Malaya in the future and therefore the over-population problem of Singapore could be solved. One could admit that a merger with the Federation of Malaya is a long way off but, Sir, I say, "No, it is not so."

    Thirdly, I think the Government has shown some favouritism in its generous grant to the Family Planning Association. The Member for Telok Ayer

Column: 3159

stated that there is a tendency to instability in this country which is mainly due to the high population of youth but when the Chinese Young Men's Association asked for a grant from the Government to help to solve their financial difficulties the Minister for Finance said that he will consider the matter - consider for many, many months! I cannot see which is more important, the Chinese Young Men's Association or the Family Planning Association. Everybody agrees that family planning is a controversial problem. I am sure that everybody would like to support the Chinese Young Men's Association, and yet the result for the Chinese Young Men's Association has been adverse.

    Sir, I strongly support the mover of the amendment.

    Mr Lim Koon Teck (Paya Lebar): Mr Speaker, Sir, until we can live in space and drink sea water, we must come down to earth and face facts as they are. The only objection so far as I can see to this vote for family planning is the question of $83,000 having been spent on salaries and provident fund. When we look at it from this point of view - that there is hardly any other expense except the hiring of people to do the work of helping and giving advice to women then it must necessarily be so that three-quarters of the funds of this Association has been spent on salaries.

    Another remark was, "Why was such a little amount raised by private subscriptions?" That is because most people feel that this work should be done by Government. It is really a Government responsibility and this has been adopted by many countries. I can say that it is now being supported by Governments in India, China, Japan and Pakistan but I say that if this branch of work were to be carried out by the Government and its hospitals I am afraid that it will achieve less than half of what can be done by voluntary people who without selfish reasons come forward to work hard because they feel that it is essential for the welfare of our state.

Column: 3160



    Sir, the Federation last week voiced great concern over the difficulties of finding employment for an extra million workers in the next ten years. Their population is now nearly eight million. With our population of about 1½ million, we are going to get nearly 400,000 people seeking employment in ten years time and we in Singapore are suffering from lack of space with no new lands to open up. If the Federation with its huge hinterland could worry about this increase in the workers and finding employment for them what must we in Singapore think? Shall we get into the position of what Japan and China are in today where abortion is legalised? In Japan, any medical practitioner can perform an abortion for two reasons: one, if it is for health reasons of the mother; and two, when it is economically essential for the family to have the abortion performed. Is it not better Sir, for us to plan to avoid the abhorrent position that may and will arise if we do not support the Family Planning Association and the very good work that it is doing today?

10.30 a.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, I usually have the greatest respect for the Member for Changi (Mr Lim Cher Kheng) for his reasoning and his way of tackling a problem but my respect for him this morning has been somewhat shattered because the arguments he put forward in support of the motion before the House are actually arguments in favour of the grant to be given to the Family Planning Association. He speaks of the youth problem and the delinquents that we are facing now. If we do not have family planning on a voluntary basis to restrict the birth of young children how can we ever provide places for the children in schools? As it is, I have to revise my estimates every six months. I have to see that more buildings are being constructed to provide places for the children going to secondary schools and if we allow things to go on as they are, we will never be able to introduce compulsory education. No government, as far as I can see, will

Column: 3161

be able to do that if the increase in population is allowed to go on without a check. I am glad that the Member for Paya Lebar (Mr Lim Koon Teck) mentioned about Japan where abortion is legalised for two reasons.

    For the third time, I think I have to contradict the Member for Bukit Panjang (Mr Goh Tong Liang) who describes the Family Planning Association as "useless". I say for the third time that it is useful and I take off my hat to many of the voluntary workers of the Association who are doing a useful job. Instead of condemning them, I think they deserve all the praise from us.

    Mr Soh Ghee Soon (Cairnhill): Sir, I am a new Member of this Assembly and I must confess that until lately I did not know how much good the Singapore Family Planning Association had been doing for the public of Singapore. They must have been in existence for at least eight years now. I am glad that I received a report lately giving me a clearer picture of what the Singapore Family Planning Association had done. When I received the Estimates, my first impulse was to vote against family planning. I feel that a project like this should be supported by the public and not by Government. On going through the report, I found that the Association had done very goo4 work and, if given a chance, I think they would do better. It is nonsense to say that it is a pleasure to have many children and that the Chinese are proud to have many children. We realise the hardship of the people who have too many children and not being able to give them a good education. It is a sin and by not giving such children a good education, we are encouraging them, to join bad elements. We are fighting against such things.

    It is not true to say that Singapore is not over-crowded. Only lately, I heard-if not in this Chamber it was somewhere else-that Singapore is one of the most populated areas in the whole world and that it will be very much so in another 10 or 15 years. At the moment we cannot cope with the housing problem. Look at the Singapore Improvement Trust. Thousands and thousands

Column: 3162

are still on its waiting list and the situation has not improved although many buildings have been put up; about the same number of applicants for houses are still on its waiting list. It shows that we cannot even house them.

    I therefore feel that family planning must be strongly supported by Government and I even think that $120,000 is not sufficiently enough to do the good work that they are doing for Singapore.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Bukit Panjang (Mr Goh Tong Liang) has clearly indicated to us this morning that this is the third time we are debating this subject It appears to me that this subject has become very stale and it will carry on and on year by year if we are going to continue debating this subject every time it comes up during the Committee of Supply. Last year, the Member for Bukit Panjang was defeated for the second time and I told him that he was trying to flog a dead horse. Now this morning I am not going to repeat that same phrase again. The mover of the amendment may expect to succeed after some canvassing or so outside this Chamber. If he succeeds with his amendment, good luck to him.

    But what I notice, Sir, is the question of the increase in the grant. I think we should concentrate more on the increase in the grant rather that on the actual grant itself. In the year before last, the Association was granted $80,000. Last year, it came up to $100,000. It is now $120,000. As one Member pointed out just now, where is this all going to end? Are we going to increase again the grant next year to $140,000, and so on? As I said, then year after year we will have to debate this same subject. Now if this grant is going to increase year by year, would it be fair to the other charitable organisations? As I go through the list, I find that some of the grants to these organisations have decreased rather than increased - apart from those which remain with the same grant - such as the grant to Voluntary Institutions for Children which has come down to $295,000 from $350,000, the maintenance of St. Andrew's Orthopaedic Hospital from $5,000 to $3,000, and many other

Column: 3163

items (I have not gone through the list carefully). So, Sir, I think that now is the time we should stop the increase in the grant rather than to stop the whole grant.

    If the Government is going to grant $120,000 and increase it every year, what about the application of the Chinese Young Men's Christian Association? I believe that the Hon. the Financial Secretary said that it is still receiving consideration. How long is the application going to receive consideration? As far as I know, the application was submitted early this year. I brought up the issue last year and the Hon. the Financial Secretary promised to look into it last year during the Committee of Supply. One year has elapsed and nothing appears in the Estimates for the Chinese Young Men's Christian Association? Why is that, Sir?

    Sir, it would be very unfair to cut out the whole grant altogether. As the hon, nominated Member Mr R. C. H. Lim pointed out, how is the Family Planning Association going to function? Also we would be subject to legal expenses in paying extra salaries to the staff of the Association on the termination of their services. Are we prepared for that? I understand that the Member for Cairnhill (Mr Soh Ghee Soon) said that this Association has been going on for eight years and that we have been giving a grant to it for quite a number of years. The thing to do now, I think, is to stop the increase. If Members are not satisfied with the functions of the Association, let us get a Committee going then and investigate into the actual functions of the Association. If the Association is doing pretty well and doing good work as the Member for Cairnhill said, then let the Committee recommend to the Government that there should be an increase in the grant rather than stop the whole grant. If the Committee feels that the Association is doing work which is against the interests of the public, then it can either stop the grant or stop the increase in the grant, Sir,It will be unfair now to cut off the grant altogether to an Association that has been going on for years. I do not think that it is right, Sir. Last year, I abstained from the issue, because I was neither for or against. I am quite happy

Column: 3164

so long as the Association carries on and maintains itself and I think, to be fair to the Association as well as to the Member who moved the amendment, we should cut off this increase in the grant. So may I have your guidance if I can move an amendment to the amendment, Sir? With your permission, Sir, I intend to move it to debate-

    The Chairman: Order. The hon. Member no doubt knows Standing Order 69 (7) which reads:

    "Any Member may move an amendment to the schedule to reduce by $ the sum to be allotted for any head of expenditure in respect of any sub-head or item therein, but at least two clear days' notice of such amendment shall be given."

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not trying to move an original amendment as the amendment appears on the Order Paper. My intention is to amend the amendment and I wonder if that is in order. My intention is to leave out "$120,000", and insert "20,000" which would retain the old grant of $100,000.

    The Chairman: My reading of financial procedure as a whole is such that I think I must disagree. I cannot allow an amendment to an amendment of that nature because, if the hon. Member will look at paragraph (8), it reads:

    "When several such amendments are proposed to the same sub-head or item, the amendment seeking the smallest reduction shall be first proposed and an amendment to omit the sub-head or item shall only be proposed after all motions for reduction have been disposed of."

    It follows therefore that the financial procedure presupposes that there should be specific amendments to each sub-head or each item. Therefore, I cannot allow an amendment to the amendment.

    Mr Braga: On a point of further clarification, Sir. If no amendment can be moved to the original amendment, I would like to enquire whether the mover of the original amendment could amend his amendment.

    The Chairman: The principle is still the same.

Column: 3165



    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Mr Speaker, Sir, since I am ruled out of order to move my amendment to the amendment, may I then, Sir, ask the Government to look into this suggestion of mine that a Committee be formed to investigate or to look into the functions of the Association and then recommend either to this Assembly to the Government next year the grant that should be made?

    The Minister for Commerce and Industry (Mr J. M. Jumabhoy): Mr Speaker, as the Deputy Speaker stated just now, the Estimates Committee could go into that matter.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Thank you.

    Mr G. A. P. Sutherland (Nominated): Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not propose to adduce any arguments in support of my view which is unchanged because I do not want to bore the House with reiteration but one thing that has stiffened my resistance is the amount of lobbying I have had from religious bodies who emphasise that they are putting forward their point of view from a secular and an economic basis and not from a religious basis.

    One is indeed either in favour of family planning or against it. I do not believe that any amount of debate would change anybody's views on the subject. One either holds the scientific point of view or the superstitious. For myself, I am inclined to the former.

    One point, Sir, that occurs to me in connection with the remarks made by the Member for Changi (Mr Lim Cher Kheng): it may not have occurred to him that in looking for greater Lebensraum in interplanetary space, he might find perhaps that the population, if any, of Mars and Venus - especially Venus - might be more advanced in birth control than we are.

    The Financial Secretary (Mr T. M. Hart): This item has not been placed in the estimates in order to provoke a debate but because Government thinks that the grant should be made and it would perhaps be appropriate for me at this stage to give the reasons why.

    I think, Sir, it is generally accepted, as a matter of policy, in most civilized countries, that instruction and advice in

Column: 3166

matters connected with family planning should be available to all those who wish to obtain it. As will be seen from the voluminous correspondence which has been exchanged between the various organisations interested in this matter, in most countries, the state either undertakes the task, or gives financial assistance to voluntary bodies, or does both, to promote the cause of family planning. There is no doubt in the mind of the government that family planning is, under modern conditions, an essential service and one which does a very great deal to dispel ignorance, to alleviate misery, poverty and hardship, and to promote a full and happy family life. Al, though this advice can be obtained on request from Government hospitals and clinics, it is considered preferable, in the conditions which exist in Singapore at the present time, that the ground-work in what must be an expanding service should be done by a voluntary organisation like the Family Planning Association which can, I think, make a more personal contact with the population than can an impersonal Government department.

10.45 a.m.

    In one of the letters in the barrage of correspondence which has been laid down, criticisms were made on the inefficiency of the Family Planning Association. I have been into the affairs of the Association with considerable care knowing that the matter would come up once more for debate in the Assembly and I can say that I am satisfied that the Association is a very efficient organisation run on professional lines. Its overhead expenses are low. I think perhaps this is because so much voluntary assistance is given by a dedicated band of women. The salaries of its paid staff are in no way excessive when compared with the emoluments of comparable Government officers. In this connection, I should say that the proportion which emoluments bear to total expenditure is in no way out of the ordinary for a body which does nothing but render services to the public. I am satisfied that the grant which Government makes to the Association is well and properly spent. It is a fact that the Government grant does make up a large proportion of the

Column: 3167

income of the Association and that these grants have increased considerably over the years but the increase in the amount of the grant has been met by a corresponding increase in the activities of the Association as an examination of the statistics provided in the Annual Report will show. At the present time, it will be seen from the Annual Report, that the Association conducts four daily clinics, one weekly clinic, eight bi-weekly clinics, nine fortnightly clinics and three monthly clinics and that the attendance at these clinics now averages close on 15,000 persons a year. I am satisfied that any addition to the grant will result in a further expansion of the very desirable activities of the Association.

    I feel, Sir, that this question of whether a grant should or should not be given is a matter which should be decided on what I might call practical humanitarian grounds, and that religious considerations should not be taken into account. I feel that if hon. Members will weigh the pros and cons of the matter, they will come to the conclusion, as the Government has done, that it is the duty of the state either directly or by financing an agency or by both means to make available to all those who wish to obtain it in whatever walk of life they may be, information about the planning of families and kindred matters.

    I would also like hon. Members to ponder the consequences which would befall if this grant were not to be made in the coming year. It would mean that the activities of the Association would have to cease and it would cause untold misery to all those who have voluntarily gone to it for assistance.

    With regard to the suggestion that the affairs and activities of the Association should be examined by a Committee, I would repeat what the nominated Member Mr R. C. H. Lim said, namely that this is a matter which can properly be gone into by the Estimates Committee of this House.

    Mr R. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no doubt that the Association is doing very good work but my point is that when Government is paying 85 or 90 per cent of the money, it is the Government's duty to run this Association

Column: 3168

or an agency. What Government control is there over such an agency? That answer has not been given at all. The Hon. the Financial Secretary said only that he was satisfied. There has been some objection to the grant as it is public money.

    Sir, during the debate on this subject, I promised yesterday to get the dates of the letters addressed to the Government from the Chinese Young Men's Christian Association. A letter was addressed in February 1957 and a reminder was sent in May 1957. It was to the fact that they were owing over $350,000 and paying interest on it. It is December now and yet the Government has not come to any decision so far. It is most disgusting.

    Sir, the Ramakrishna Mission wrote also in February but the Hon. the Chief Minister explained yesterday that they were asked for some particulars and that the onus lay with the Mission to furnish such particulars to the Government.
